The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Abandoned motor vehicle means a motor vehicle or trailer: (1) That has been left by the owner or some person acting for the owner with an automobile dealer, repairman or wrecker service for repair or for some other reason and has not been called for by such owner or other person within a period of 30 days after the time agreed upon; or within 30 days after such vehicle is turned over to such dealer, repairman or wrecker service when no time is agreed upon; or within 30 days after the completion of necessary repairs; (2) That is left unattended on a public street, road, or highway or other public property for a period of at least five days and when it reasonably appears to a law enforcement officer that the individual who left such motor vehicle unattended does not intend to return and remove such motor vehicle; (3) That has been lawfully towed onto the property of another at the request of a law enforcement officer and left there for a period of not less than 30 days without anyone's having made claim thereto; (4) That has been lawfully towed onto the property of another at the request of a property owner on whose property the vehicle was abandoned and left there for a period of not less than 30 days without the owner's having made claim thereto; or (5) That has been left unattended on private property for a period of not less than 30 days without anyone's having made claim thereto. Motor vehicle or vehicle means motor vehicle or trailer. Owner means the owner, lessor, lessee, security interest holders, and all lienholders as shown on the records of the state department of revenue. (Code 1986, § 14-26) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1. Sec. 74-112. - Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person, either as owner, occupant, lessee, agent, tenant or otherwise, to store or deposit, or cause or permit to be stored or deposited, any abandoned motor vehicle upon any public or private property within the city. (Code 1986, § 14-27) Sec. 74-113. - Removal—Generally. Any abandoned, junked or discarded motor vehicle shall be removed upon ten days' written notice to the owner or occupant of any premises upon which the motor vehicle is stored or deposited, or to the owner thereof if the identity of such owner of the motor vehicle can be ascertained through license plates or otherwise. If such motor vehicle is not removed after ten days' written notice, the police department of the city shall remove same or cause the removal and sale at the cost of the owner or occupant of the premises, or the owner of such motor vehicle or motor vehicles, if such owner can be ascertained. Sale shall be made to the highest of two bids obtained from dealers in such property. (Code 1986, § 14-28) Sec. 74-114. - Same—Notice to owner and state. (a) Any person who removes a motor vehicle from public or private property at the request of someone other than the owner or who stores any motor vehicle which has been left unattended shall seek the identity of the owner of such vehicle and shall, within 15 days of the day such vehicle became an abandoned motor vehicle, give notice in writing to the state department of revenue and the Georgia Bureau of Investigation, stating the manufacturer's vehicle identification number, the license number, the fact that such vehicle is an abandoned motor vehicle, and the present location of such vehicle, and requesting the name and address of all owners, lessors, lessees, security interest holders, and lienholders of such vehicle. If a person removing or storing the vehicle has knowledge of facts that reasonably indicate the vehicle is registered or titled in a certain other state, he shall check the motor vehicle records of that other state in the attempt to ascertain the identity of the owner of the vehicle. (b) Upon ascertaining the owner of such motor vehicle, the person removing or storing such vehicle shall, within three days, by certified or registered mail, notify the owner, lessors, lessees, security interest holders, and lienholders of the location of such vehicle and of the fact that such vehicle is deemed abandoned and shall be disposed of if not redeemed. (c) If the identity of the owner of such motor vehicle cannot be ascertained, the person removing or storing such vehicle shall place an advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where such vehicle was obtained or, if there is no newspaper in the county, shall post such advertisement at the county courthouse in such place where other public notices are posted. Such advertisement shall run in the newspaper once a week for two consecutive weeks or shall remain posted at the courthouse for two consecutive weeks. The advertisement shall contain a complete description of the motor vehicle, its license and manufacturer's vehicle identification numbers, the location where such vehicle was initially left unattended by the owner, the present location of such vehicle, and the fact that such vehicle is deemed abandoned and shall be disposed of if not redeemed. (Code 1986, § 14-29) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-2. Secs. 74-115—74-145. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - RAILROADS[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— Railroad companies, O.C.G.A. § 46-8-1 et seq.
Sec. 74-146. - Railroad trains blocking streets. It shall be unlawful for any person responsible for and/or operating a train upon any railroad track within the limits of the city to cause any such train to block any street within the city longer than ten minutes. (Code 1986, § 20-1) Sec. 74-147. - Boarding, alighting. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person other than a passenger or employee to board any train within the city, whether such train is in motion or not, except persons loading baggage or assisting an invalid. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person other than a passenger or employee of the railroad company engaged in the operation of such train to jump on or off any moving train within the city. (Code 1986, § 20-3) Sec. 74-148. - Parking distance from street center. It shall be unlawful for any person responsible for or operating a train upon any railroad track within the city to stop or stand any car thereof nearer than 75 feet from the center of any street therein. (Code 1986, § 20-4)

div.head: Chapter 78 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Ownership, operation of utility system, § 21; authority to require water, sewer connections, § 27(o); sale, other disposition of public property, § 29. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. State Law reference— Public utilities and public transportation, O.C.G.A. title 46.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 78-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Utility service means and includes water, sewer, gas, electricity, solid waste collection and/or any other like service furnished by the city to consumers or beneficiaries thereof. (Code 1986, § 24-201) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 78-2. - Service to property. It shall be unlawful for any person to tap into any utility service on any property without a permit for the same, and after the owner of such property has signed an application for such utility service and has paid the appropriate fees. (Code 1986, § 24-1) Sec. 78-3. - Violations of rules. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the rules governing or pertaining to any utility department. (Code 1986, § 24-2(a)) Sec. 78-4. - Access to premises and extensions of system. Duly authorized agents of the city shall have access at all reasonable hours to the premises of the consumer for the purpose of installing or removing city property, inspecting, reading and testing meters, or for any other purpose in connection with the furnishing or providing of any utility service. (Code 1986, § 24-3) Sec. 78-5. - Application for service. Any person desiring any utility service must first make application to the city clerk and pay the deposit as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1986, § 24-27) Sec. 78-6. - Vacating premises; notice required, charges to be paid. Any consumer using any utility service or any property owner where any utility service is used, must give notice to the city clerk upon vacating such premises or upon desiring to discontinue such service. Upon failure to give such notice the rates will be charged to him the same as if such utility service was used. Such party cannot contract for service elsewhere in the city until all unpaid bills have been paid at the place vacated. (Code 1986, § 24-32) Sec. 78-7. - City not required to furnish taps and services. If because of unusual costs or circumstances it is not feasible for the city to furnish utility taps, connections or services, it shall not be required to do so. (Code 1986, § 24-202) Secs. 78-8—78-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CHARGES AND BILLING[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Collection, enforcement of utility charges, § 22.
Sec. 78-41. - Rates, charges. The rates and charges imposed by the city for utility services furnished by the city shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1986, §§ 24-221—24-252) Sec. 78-42. - Billing; collection; penalties. (a) Bills for utility services shall be rendered monthly, and each service rendered shall be listed as a separate item on the bill. Such bills shall also set forth the total charge. No partial payment shall be accepted unless approved by the city clerk. There shall be no discount allowed for prompt payment. If any bill shall not be paid before the tenth day following the original date of billing, it shall be declared delinquent; and the city clerk or his designated assistant shall mail out to each customer whose bill is delinquent a notice of delinquency, which notice shall be deemed to be a last and final notice. If any bill shall not be paid within 20 days from the original date of billing, utility service to the delinquent customer shall be immediately shut off and discontinued. Service shall not be restored or turned on until the delinquent bill has been paid in full, together with a disconnection charge and a reconnection charge, which is set by the mayor and council from time to time to be recorded in the minutes of the city council meeting. (b) Late charges. All bills for electrical service are payable monthly within ten days of mailing of the bill. An additional ten percent is hereby assessed on all bills not paid within ten days of the mailing of same. (Code 1986, § 24-203; Ord. No. 00-07, § 3, 12-18-00) Sec. 78-43. - Disconnection. Any person desiring disconnection of any utility service shall give notice thereof to the city. Such utility service shall be considered discontinued immediately upon delivery of a notice of the name and address of such customer to the respective utility department. Sec. 78-44. - Payment of utility bills by check. Payment of a utility bill by check shall not be considered payment thereof until the check is honored by the bank on which it is drawn. The giver of any check for payment of a utility bill that was not honored by the bank on which it was drawn shall lose all rights to discount on such utility bill if the bill is not paid by its due date, and such utility shall be discontinued to such customer if the bill is not paid on or before its due date. In all cases of dishonored checks an additional cost as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk shall be added to the account. (Code 1986, § 24-204) State Law reference— Fee for dishonored check, O.C.G.A. § 16-9-20(a)(2). Sec. 78-45. - Discontinuance of service, reconnection charges. (a) All delinquent utility service accounts shall have service discontinued ten days following the delinquent date. After service to a delinquent account has been discontinued, the same shall not be restored until such account has been paid, plus payment of a delinquent and reconnection fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (b) In cases where there are two or more accounts with the city, whether residential, business or otherwise, when any one of such accounts shall become delinquent, all other such accounts shall likewise be considered delinquent and service shall be discontinued to all such accounts until such time as all accounts are paid and in good standing. (c) The city reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for the following additional reasons: (1) To prevent fraud or abuse. (2) Consumer's willful disregard of the city's rules. (3) Emergency repairs. (4) Insufficiency of supply due to circumstances beyond the city's control. (5) Legal processes. (6) Direction of public authorities. (7) Strike, riot, fire, flood, unavoidable accident. (Code 1986, § 24-205) Sec. 78-46. - No new service to delinquent accounts. No new utility account shall be opened or utilities furnished to any household or business establishment wherein a person who owes a delinquent bill actually resides in the household requesting such new services or the person requesting new services for such business establishment actually is an operator thereof. This section shall apply in all such cases even though the request made for such new services is not made in the name of such person or persons who owe such delinquent bill but made in the name of a person or persons who do not owe a delinquent bill. All such persons requesting such new services shall truthfully answer all questions asked by the city official to whom such application is made. (Code 1986, § 24-207) Sec. 78-47. - Complaints and adjustments. (a) Complaints. If the consumer believes his bill to be in error, he shall present his claim, in person, at city hall before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The consumer may pay such bill under protest, and such payment shall not prejudice his claim. (b) Adjustments. (1) The city will make a special meter reading at the request of a consumer for a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk; however, if such special reading discloses that the meter was over-read, no charge will be made. (2) Water meters will be tested at the request of the consumer upon payment to the city of an amount as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk for making the test; however, if the meter is found to over-register beyond three percent of the correct volume, no charge will be made. (3) If the seal of a meter is broken by other than the city's representative or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the consumer shall pay an amount estimated from the record of his previous bills and/or from other proper data. (Code 1986, § 24-208) Sec. 78-48. - Multiunits with single meter. All multiunit housing projects, including trailer parks, that have a single water meter connection will be required to pay for the amount of water used as measured by the master meter or the number of units times the individual minimum rate (availability charge) for a single-family residence, whichever is greater. (Code 1986, § 24-209) Secs. 78-49—78-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY[3]

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 78-116. - Separate connections. Each consumer must have a separate connection to the city water and sewer mains, and a separate meter must be placed for each consumer. The city may install its meter at or near the property line or, at the city's option, on the consumer's property within three feet of the property line. (Code 1986, § 24-52) Sec. 78-117. - Turning on water. Water shall be turned on only by persons in the employ of the city, and in no case will the water be turned on until the consumer has met the requirements of this chapter; after this is done and the plumber's work is inspected and found to be done according to the regulations of the city, the water will be turned on by the city. The city reserves the right to refuse service or to disconnect service unless the consumer's lines or pipings are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross connection or backflow. (Code 1986, § 24-54) Sec. 78-118. - Unlawful use of water. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person supplied with water to allow the use of the water for any other purpose than that described in his application, nor shall he supply water in any way to any other person without written consent of the city pursuant to city standards. He shall not permit others to use his hose or attachments or leave them exposed to the use of others. For willful or unreasonable waste, concealment or neglect or violation of any of these rules, the city shall have the right to stop the supply of water; and the consumer may be charged with a violation of this Code. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to use water for any purposes from the connection of another person, or from a public hydrant or other connection with the city mains, without a permit therefor, and without paying the charges therefor. (Code 1986, § 24-55) Sec. 78-119. - Illegal use of water from waterworks. It shall be unlawful for any person in any way to defile or pollute or attempt to defile or pollute the water in any reservoir, pipe or cistern connected with the waterworks of the city or to take water from any hydrant, or carry the same for any use whatever, without authority therefor. (Code 1986, § 24-56) Sec. 78-120. - Extension of water, sewer service. Any property owner of realty within the city may obtain a sewerage and/or water extension to the most feasible place adjacent to his property provided the extension is within 400 feet of an existing main. Extensions in excess of 400 feet from an existing main must be approved by the mayor and council. Such connection shall be subject to the following conditions: (1) The property owner shall assure immediate use of the water and sewerage facilities so provided by the city. (2) The property owner shall pay, prior to the commencement of construction, the cost of such sewerage and/or water extension and shall grant or convey or shall cause to be granted or conveyed to the city a permanent easement right-of-way across any property traversed by the water and sewer lines. (3) Extension shall be made in accordance with specifications required by the city and shall pass all inspections required by the city. (4) Such improvements and extensions shall remain at all times the property of the city without any property rights accruing therein to the property owner financing such extension and/or improvement. (5) Where a meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a consumer, a suitable place shall be provided by the consumer therefor, unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. (6) In order to be received as a consumer and entitled to receive water from the city's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the city's water system. All applicants by becoming consumers of the city covenant and agree that so long as they continue to be consumers of the city they will not permit the connection of any private wells on their property to the city's water system. (7) No water or sewer extension will be made to serve any customer outside the corporate limits of the city unless approved by the mayor and council. (Code 1986, § 24-57; Ord. No. 2013-7, 2-4-13) Sec. 78-121. - Liability of city. There shall be no claim against the city for damages by reason of the bursting of any street main, service pipe or cock, or the shutting off of water for repairs, extensions or connections or for any accidental failure in the water supply. (Code 1986, § 24-58) Sec. 78-122. - Water use restrictions. (a) Purpose. It is the purpose of this section to impose restrictions for outdoor water use within the city. (b) Definitions. When used in this section: (1) "Address" means the "house number" (a numeric or alphanumeric designation) that, together with the street name, describes a physical location of a specific property. "Even-numbered address" means a house number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or no house number. "Odd-numbered address" means a house number ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. (2) "Declared drought response level" means one of four levels of drought that can be declared based on the severity of drought conditions, with one being the least severe and four being the most severe. (c) Applicability. This section shall apply to outdoor watering using the city water supply system as the source of water. (d) Outdoor water use schedule during nondrought periods. Outdoor water use other than exempted activities shall occur only as follows: (1) Odd-numbered addresses: outdoor water use is allowed on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. (2) Even-numbered addresses: outdoor water use is allowed on Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. (e) Outdoor water use schedule during declared drought response levels. (1) Drought response levels shall be determined by the Director of the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources (EPD). (2) During declared drought conditions, outdoor water use other than activities exempted in subsection (f) of this section shall occur only during scheduled hours on the scheduled days. (3) Declared drought response level one—Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 12:00 midnight. a. Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. b. Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. c. Use of hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing is prohibited. (4) Declared drought response level two—Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. a. Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. b. Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. c. The following uses are prohibited: 1. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. 2. Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks and driveways except when necessary for public health and safety. (5) Declared drought response level three—Outdoor water use may occur on the scheduled day within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. a. The scheduled day for odd-numbered addresses is Sunday. b. The scheduled day for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways is Saturday. c. The following uses are prohibited: 1. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. 2. Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, except when necessary for public health and safety. 3. Filling installed swimming pools except when necessary for health care or structural integrity. 4. Washing vehicles, such as cars, boats, trailers, motorbikes, airplanes, golf carts. 5. Washing buildings or structures except for immediate fire protection. 6. Noncommercial fundraisers, such as car washes. 7. Using water for ornamental purposes, such as fountains, reflecting pools, and waterfalls except when necessary to support aquatic life. (6) Declared drought response level four—No outdoor water use is allowed, other than for activities exempted in subsection (f) of this section, or as the EPD Director may order. (f) Exemptions. (1) These restrictions shall not apply to the following outdoor water uses: a. Capture and re-use of cooling system condensate or storm water in compliance with applicable local ordinances. b. Re-use of gray water in compliance with applicable ordinances. (2) The following established landscape water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of this rule. a. Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater. b. Irrigation of personal food gardens. (3) Newly (in place less than 30 days) installed landscapes are subject to the following: a. Irrigation of newly installed landscapes is allowed any day of the week, but only during allowed hours for the drought response level in effect, for a period of 30 days following installation. No watering is allowed during drought response level four. b. For new landscapes installed by certified or licensed professionals, commercial exemptions apply. (4) The following golf course outdoor water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of this rule. a. Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater. b. Irrigation of fairways during times of non-drought and declared drought response level one. c. Irrigation of tees during times of non-drought and declared drought response levels one, two and three. d. Irrigation of greens. (5) The following commercial outdoor water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of this rule. a. Professionally certified or licensed landscapers, golf course contractors, and sports turf landscapers: during installation and 30 days following installation only. Professional landscapers must be certified or licensed for commercial exemptions to apply. b. Irrigation contractors: during installation and as needed for proper maintenance and adjustments only. c. Sod producers. d. Ornamental growers. e. Fruit and vegetable growers. f. Retail garden centers. g. Hydro-seeding. h. Power-washing. i. Construction sites. j. Producers of food and fiber. k. Car washes. l. Other activities essential to daily business. m. Watering-in of pesticides and herbicides on turf. (g) Penalties. A warning shall be imposed upon persons found guilty of a first violation of this article. A fine of $50.00 shall be imposed upon persons found guilty of a second violation of this article. A fine of $100.00 shall be imposed upon persons found guilty of a third violation of this article. A fine of $300.00 shall be imposed upon persons found guilty of a fourth violation of this article. Nonpayment of any fine imposed under this article within 24 hours following imposition of such fine shall result in termination of water service to the premises where the violation occurred. (Ord. No. 04-03, §§ 1—7, 7-19-04) Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-03, adopted July 19, 2004, enacted new provisions which in effect superseded provisions formerly set out as § 78-122 of this Code.
